 University Master Space Plan – 
Loyola Campus 
 Major construction and renovation projects overview 2000-2015 
 The  Richard J. Renaud Science Complex  (33,000 square metres) was constructed as a teaching and research facility for various arts and science departments. The building was officially opened in September 2003. 
 Richard J. Renaud Science Complex  
 The former Drummond Science Building was renovated and expanded to house the departments of Communication Studies and Journalism. The  Communication Studies and Journalism Building  reopened in September 2005. 
 Renovation of the  Vanier Extension  provided new teaching and research facilities, including the construction of multi-functional high-tech classrooms to be used by the Department of Applied Human Sciences. This work was completed in the summer of 2005. 
 Upgrading of the  Recreation and Athletics Complex  included the installation of state-of-the-art artificial surfaces to create two new playing fields; installation of permanent outdoor lighting for the playing fields; and installation of temporary stands to replace deteriorating stadium seating. In 2009, the south fields was equipped with a seasonal dome. In 2012, the Ed Meagher Arena was renovated to offer an ice rink that meets NHL standards. 
 The  Jesuit Residence  was completely renovated to provide 52 new residence bedrooms for occupancy in August 2006. 
 The  PERFORM Centre , constructed in 2011, is a unique research facility that received LEED Gold certification. 
 The  Centre for Structural and Functional Genomics , constructed in 2011, received a LEED Gold certification. 
 The  Vanier Library Building  was partially renovated in 2013 to integrate compact shelving and to house Collection Services. 
 Hingston Hall was partly transformed into a a student residence and two new amphitheatres were built. 
 The Refectory was transformed into Loyola Jesuit Hall and Conference Centre in 2011.
